2802.notes:
MORAL TEACHINGS AND COMMITMENT

Moral Teachings

The objective of the chapter is to help pupils to:

1. be aware of the importance of moral teachings from the Bible, Holy Qur'an and African Traditional Religious Wise Sayings

2. understand the importance of commitment and its practical implications.

Morality

Moral is defined as the ideas of how to behave. Moral teachings are knowledge obtained from good behavior.

1. Morality is when one conforms to a code of conduct put fon/vard by society or some other group, such as a religion.

2. Morality shows the distinction between good and bad.

3. A person who engages in activities that are generally accepted by society or conforms to standards set by his religion is said to be a morally upright person or has good morals.

Moral Teachings

1. Moral teachings are principles or teachings that guide an individual to appreciate what is right from wrong or good from evil.

2. The three main religions in Ghana have moral teachings that are aimed at training their members towards acceptable religious standards for God.

3. The moral teachings of Christians are found in the Holy Bible and that of Islam are found in the Holy Qur'an.

4. The African Traditional Religion have moral teachings which are not documented but are found in "Traditional Religious Wise Sayings"

Moral Teaching In The Bible

The Holy Bible offers many moral teachings to Christians today. Most of the moral teachings are obtained from the following text:

The Ten Commandments-Exodus 20:1 to 17. "

The Sermon on the Mount-Matthew 5: 1 to 12.

The Book of Proverbs.

The Book of Ephesians 5: 15 to 21.

The Epistle of James 1 to 5.

Moral Lessons from The Ten Commandments

# The Ten Commandments were given by God to the House of Israel through Moses on Mount Sinai (or Horeb)

# It consisted of ten (10) main laws (Decalogue) written on two tablets of stones.

# The Ten Commandments are recognized as a moral foundation in Christianity.

Refer to Exodus 20: 1 to 20.

1.The First Commandment: "You shall have no other gods before me." The moral teaching is that God is the only true creator and the only God humanity should worship and adore. God is the only object of worship. Humanity must worship Him alone.

2.The Second Commandment: "You shall not make for yourself any idol in the form of anything in heaven above, or on the earth beneath or in the waters below." The moral teaching is that humanity should not use any created item or object to make an idol or object of worship. It is sinful to make any image with wood, stone, metal, water, paintings, heavenly bodies such as stars, moon, su.n or planet and worship them.

3.The Third Commandment: "You shall not misuse the name of the Lord your God." The moral teaching is that humanity should desist from using the name of the Lord when we know that we are telling lies or cheating others. We should not swear using the name of God. God's name should be respected, praised and adored at all times.

4.The Fourth Commandment: "Remember the Sabbath day and keep it Holy." God commanded the House of Israel to work in six days and rest on the seventh day or Sabbath. This is because it was with a great hand that he rescued them from Egypt. So they must rest on the Sabbath (Saturday). The moral lesson to humanity is that we should allocate time for resting. The body must be rested after a hard day's work so that it can regain its lost energy. This will reduce stress, improve one's health and renew the mind.

5.The Fifth Commandment: "Honour your father and mother; so that you may live long in the land the Lord your God is giving you."

The moral lessons are as follows:

i. Children should respect .their parents, siblings, teachers, seniors and the elderly in society.

ii. People should obey laws, rules and regulations that are set by the state, schools, and the community.

iii. Every individual should support the parents in cash and kind when he or she has the ability to do so.

iv. God blesses those who honour their parents and guardian. Refer to Colossians 3:20.

v. As children of God we should be polite, hard working, and dedicated to our parents.

6.The Sixth Commandment: "You shall not commit murder". The moral teaching is that:

No individual should attempt to take his or her life or that of other person(s).

i. By aborting an unplanned pregnancy one has violated this commandment. We should live a chaste life and God will bless us in His own time.

ii. One should not fight or throw objects at others since this can lead to accidental deaths.

7.The Seventh Commandment: "You should not commit adultery." Adultery occurs when a married man or woman engages in sexual relationship outside the marriage. The moral teachings are that:

i. Husbands and wives should be committed to their marriage vows.

ii. They should not keep boyfriends, mistress, or girlfriends outside their marriage.

iii. They should not solicit sex from commercial sex workers or prostitutes.

iv. God wants the sanctity of marriage to be honoured and respected by couples.

v. Married couples should remain monogamous (one-man-one-wife). That is, every man should have a wife and every wife a husband. Any arrangement beside this is adultery. Refer to Ephesians 5: 22 to 31.

8.The Eight Commandment: "You should not steal".

i. The moral teaching is that, stealing is a sinful and a criminal act punishable by the laws of the State.

ii. Individuals should respect what belongs to others and not to take advantage of them through stealing.

iii. Stealing amounts to greediness, a bad deed, evil and covetousness. God is not pleased when His children steal.

iv. All those who steal shall be punished by God either on earth or on Judgment Day. Refer to Romans 2:12 to 16; Matthew 16:27.

9.The Ninth Commandment: "You should notgive false witness or testimony against your neighbour."

i. The moral lessons are that it is unethical and criminal to do so. This can lead to prosecution and possibly imprisonment if one is found t'o have lied.

ii. Individuals who give false witnesses against their friends, class mates, neighbours, and their leaders will be punished by God.

iii. False witness against another person may lead to conï¬‚icts, misunderstanding and collapse of marriages. It can foster disunity and mistrust in society.

iv. Telling lies can deceive parents, teachers, opinion leaders, the police and the court. This is a bad habit that should be avoided at all cost.

10.The Tenth Commandment: "You shall not covert your neighbours house, wife, a maid servant, ox, or anything that belongs to your neighbour.

i. To covert means is to secretly have a strong desire for something that does not belong to you. This is morally wrong for an individual to do.

ii. A covetous person is greedy, selfish, and can kill in order to possess what does not belong to him.

iii. Morally, one should be content with what is provided for by his parents and guardian. We should not demand more than what our parents and guardian can afford.

iv. God 'is happy with those that appreciate little things He does for them.

v. We shall be blessed abundantly when we are grateful to God and our parents for what they do for us.

Importance of the Ten Commandments

1.They help us to realize the supremacy of God as the highest authority

2.They serve as a guide for honest living

3.They teach us to be content with what we have

4.They teach us to be truthful always

5.They help us to give reverence to God

6.They promote peaceful and harmonious living

7.They teach us what pleases God

8.They teach us to work hard and have time for rest

The Book of Proverbs (10 - 12)

The Book of Proverbs was written by King Solomon. It contains many wise sayings and moral teachings that humanity must appreciate and apply to their lives.

Moral Teachings from Proverb 10 To 12

1.Righteousness: Solomon taught humanity to live a righteous life that is pleasing to God. Refer to Proverbs 10:2 to 3; 31 to 32. It states that "ill-gotten treasures are of no value, but righteousness delivers from death.

2.Foolishness: The Book discourages humanity from being foolish, self-centred, slanderous, talking non-sense and being stupid. It states that "A foolish man grieves the mother." Refer to Proverbs 10 18 and 23; 10:2.

3.Humanity should fear God: Humanity should fear God Almighty because it adds more years to one's age. But, those who do not fear Him will have their life cut short. The fear of God is the beginning of wisdom. In his relationship with God, King Solomon feared God and kept His command. This is a fact of life we should emulate. Refer to Proverbs 10: 27. If one wants to live long, then he should fear God.

4.We should possess love and friendliness: The Book encourages humanity to cultivate the habit of love and friendship for fellow humankind. Love is the greatest of all the virtues; hence, humankind should love one another. Proverbs 10:12, states that "Love covers all wrong." When we show love, we will give support to those in need or helpless.

5.Hardwork: We should eschew laziness and idleness. Every person should cultivate the habit of hard work. One should use his God-given talent and resources to the service of humanity. idleness and laziness breeds poverty, hunger, evil intentions, and sinful acts. Humanity should be proactive by working hard at school, within the neighbourhood, at the workplace and within the country. Refer to Proverbs 10:4 to 5.

6.Humans should desist from any act of wickedness: A wicked person will not receive the blessings of God. Indeed, God will thwart the plans of the wicked and expose them in His own time. Refer to Proverbs 10:3 and 7. A wicked person will not find favour from others and God Almighty. When they die, their names quickly disappear or are forgotten by humanity. Their names will rot when they die. Proverbs 10:7.

7.Speech/tongue: One should control his tongue.King Solomon admonished humanity to be careful about what they say at any given time. Our words should bring blessings and not curses on others. We should avoid the use of profane language and insults that may discredit us before others. We should learn to speak politely, truthfully, and respectfully. God will bless us when we bless others and encourage them by our words. We should learn to thank others when we receive favour from them.

8.Spiritual lessons: King Solomon taught humans that when we avail ourselves to God, He will use us to satisfy.His course. In spite of his immoral life, God used him to demonstrate to the world that He (God) is the only giver of blessings, wealth, fame and wisdom.

The Sermon On The Mount (The Beatitudes â€“ Matthew 5:1-12)

The Sermon on the Mount is commonly called the Beatitudes. This is because Jesus Christ used it to demonstrate to Christians and humanity positive attributes and moral values.

Matthew 5 (introduction to the Sermon on the Mount)

1 Now when Jesus saw the crowds, he went up on a mountainside and sat down. His disciples came to him, 2and he began to teach them.

The Beatitudes

He said:

3 Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

4 Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted.

5 Blessed are the meek, for they will inherit the earth.

6 Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they will be filled.

7 Blessed are the merciful, for they will be shown mercy.

8 Blessed are the pure in heart, for they will see God.

9 Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God.

10 Blessed are those who are persecuted because of righteousness, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.

11 Blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you and falsely say all kinds of evil against you because of me. 12 Rejoice and be glad, because great is your reward in heaven, for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who were before you.

The Beatitudes teach us about:

1.Humility

2.Meekness

3.Mercy

4.Peacemakers

5.Purity

6.Spiritual hunger

Salt and Light

13 "You are the salt of the earth. But if the salt loses its saltiness, how can it be made salty again? It is no longer good for anything, except to be thrown out and trampled underfoot

14 "You are the light of the world. A town built on a hill cannot be hidden. 15 Neither do people light a lamp and put it under a bowl. Instead they put it on its stand, and it gives light to everyone in the house. 16 In the same way, let your light shine before others, that they may see your good deeds and glorify your Father in heaven.

The Fulfilment of the Law

17 "Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfil them. 18 For truly I tell you, until heaven and earth disappear, not the smallest letter, not the least stroke of a pen, will by any means disappear from the Law until everything is accomplished. 19 Therefore anyone who sets aside one of the least of these commands and teaches others accordingly will be called least in the kingdom of heaven, but whoever practices and teaches these commands will be called great in the kingdom of heaven. 20 For I tell you that unless your righteousness surpasses that of the Pharisees and the teachers of the law, you will certainly not enter the kingdom of heaven.

Murder

21 "You have heard that it was said to the people long ago, 'You shall not murder, and anyone who murders will be subject to judgment. 22 But I tell you that anyone who is angry with a brother or sister will be subject to judgment. Again, anyone who says to a brother or sister, 'Raca,' is answerable to the court. And anyone who says, 'You fool!' will be in danger of the fire of hell.

23 "Therefore, if you are offering your gift at the altar and there remember that your brother or sister has something against you, 24 " leave your gift there in front of the altar. First go and be reconciled to them; then come and offer your gift

25"Settle matters quickly with your adversary who is taking you to court. Do it while you are still together on the way, or your adversary may hand you over to the judge, and the judge may hand you over to the officer, and you may be thrown into prison. 26 Truly I tell you, you will not get out until you have paid the last penny.

Adultery

27 "You have heard that it was said, 'You shall not commit adultery. 28 But l tell you that anyone who looks at a woman lustfuliy has already committed adultery with her in his heart. 29 If your right eye causes you to stumble, gouge it out and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one part of your body than for your whole body to be thrown into hell. 30 And if your right hand causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away. It is better for you to lose one part of your body than for your whole body to go into hell.

Divorce

31 "It has been said, 'Anyone who divorces his wife must give her a certificate of divorce.' 32 But l tell you that anyone who divorces his wife, except for sexual immorality, makes her the victim of adultery, and anyone who marries a divorced woman commits adultery.

Oaths

33 Again, you have heard that it was said to the people long ago, 'Do not break your oath, but fulfil to the Lord the vows you have made.' 34 But l tell you, do not swear an oath at all: either by heaven, for it is God's throne; 35 or by the earth, for it is his footstool; or by Jerusalem, for it is the city of the Great King. 36 And do not swear by your head, for you cannot make even one hair white or black. 37 All you need to say is simply 'Yes' or 'No'; anything beyond this comes from the evil one.

Eye for Eye

38 "You have heard that it was said, 'Eye for eye, and tooth for tooth. 39 But I tell you, do not resist an evil person. If anyone slaps you on the right cheek, turn to them the other cheek also. 40 And if anyone wants to sue you and take your shirt, hand over your coat as well. 41 If anyone forces you to go one mile, go with them two miles. 42 Give to the one who asks you, and do not turn away from the one who wants to borrow from you.

Love for Enemies

43 "You have heard that it was said, love your neighbour and hate your enemy.' 44 But I tell you, love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you, 45 that you may be children of your Father in heaven. He causes his sun to rise on the evil and the good, and sends rain on the righteous and the unrighteous. 46 If you love those who love you, what reward will you get? Are not even the tax collectors doing that? 47 And if you greet only your own people, what are you doing more than others? Do not even pagans do that? Be perfect, therefore, as your heavenly Father is perfect (Continue reading the text from Mathew 6 and 7 from the Bible)

Moral Teachings Associated With the Sermon on the Mount

1.Christians should cultivate the following virtues: Humility, Repentance, Comfort, Mercy, Purity, Endurance, Avoidance of false accusations, and the promise of worshipping God.

2.Christians should inï¬‚uence the world: Christians are the salt of the world. They should be able to influence the world with the Word of God or the Good News. Their influence should impact positively on sinners, backsliders, castaways, the poor and the needy and those in spiritual bondage. Refer to Acts 13:47.

3.Humanity should avoid worldly cares: Christians should live as sons and daughters of the one True God. Their lifestyles should shine for all to see. They are to do good works, glorify God and avoid worldly things.

4.Christ fulfilled the Law: The Book also shows the relationship between Christ and the Law of Moses or the Ten Commandments. Christ came to fulfil the law and the prophets. This makes the Christian era far different from the other period. God deals with humanity today through Jesus Christ. Refer to John 14:6.to 7. Christ came to serve humanity. Thus, individuals should do same by serving others. The Word of God will endure forever. Refer to Proverbs 30:6 and Revelations 22:19.

5.It gives humanity the spiritual standard: The Sermon on the Mount shows that humanity should avoid sins that kill us spiritually.

These include murder, lust, anger, speaking evil about others, litigation, adultery, and immorality. Humankind should forgive one another sins committed so that our father in Heaven will also forgive us of our sins. Society is to reconcile, be prudent and live peacefully with one another. God will punish all evil deeds on the Day of Judgment. Refer to Proverbs 11:19; Roman 5:12 and 6:23.

6.Marriage is sacred: Morally and spiritually, marriage must be honoured as the first institution God established after creation. Husbands and wives have a big responsibility to respect their marriage vows. Divorce and adultery should be avoided by married couples. Refer to Matthew 5:31 to 32.

7.Christian love is highly required in the world: Christians should demonstrate love for one another. Their love should be extended to those who are against them and their enemies. They are to pray for their enemies and ask God's blessings for them.

8.It provides instructions on prayers and fasting: The text teaches Christians on how to fast and pray effectively. Christians are to pray in secret and not in the open like the hypocrites who shout for all to see that they are praying to God. Refer to Matthew 6:6 to 8. The Lord's Prayer gives Christians the step-by-step formula for praying effectively to God through Christ. For example, one needs to thank God, pray for the forgiveness of his sins, make the needed request and pray for his or her enemies. Refer to Matthew 6:9 to 13.

In respect of fasting, the moral lesson is that we should not look sad for others to know that we are fasting. Rather, we should look clean when fasting. God will grant us our request in His Appointed time.

Finally, we should not judge one another because all of us are sinners.

Individuals should rather ask God for what they need and allow God to answer them at His own time. We should not command God because He does not owe humanity anything.

Moral Teachings That Are Relevant From the Epistle of James 1-5

1.It teaches the mark of true religion: One should be patient and happy even during periods of trials and temptation. Christians should have firm faith that cannot be shaken by false teachings and evil spirits. Individuals should recognize that God is the only source of blessings. One should endure provocation and persecution for the course of Christ and the gospel Humanity should forsake evil and practice truth, patience, purity, and benevolence. Refer to James 1:27.

2.It exposes the mark of false profession: Morally, an individual should not be careless and forgetful. One should practise sound teachings that are heard from the Word. Humanity should not glorify and honour ill-gotten wealth. We should not discriminate against individuals on the basis that one is rich and the other is poor. God hates all forms of discrimination. Rather, He blesses the poor and the rich, the godly and ungodly, the believer and the unbeliever. Individuals should not merely profess that they are godly or Christians. Rather, we should testify our faith through our way of life. Christians should actively participate in all activities of the church. This will help spread the Word to lost souls. One should use his tongue (mouth) to bless others and not to curse with it. Christians should avoid unrest, unholy passion and worldly pleasure, double mindedness, speaking evil of others and neglect of their duties to society.

3.James warned the rich in society: Christians should be mindful of riches and how they use their wealth. The future of most rich will be disastrous and full of misery. One should not be proud of hoarding wealth and withholding the wages of the pool An individual should not seek pleasure by persecuting the righteous.

4.It encourages individuals to wait on the Lord: Humanity must be steadfast, patient and refrain from murmuring against one another. Individuals should learn useful lessons from the prophets and patriarchs by enduring pain and being patient. We should refrain from curses and swearing oaths we cannot honour. Refer to James 5:10 to 12.

5.The book also teaches humanity on how to pray and confess their sins: Prayer offers an avenue for individuals to confess their sins to God and ask for His forgiveness. it also allows humankind an opportunity to communicate with the creator, God Almighty. As a result prayer should be part of the daily activities of a person. We should be courageous to confess our sins and apologize to those we have offended.

Moral Teachings from the Book of Ephesians 5:15 - 21

The Book of Ephesians was written by the Apostle Paul to the Churches of Christ in Galatia.

1.One should be pure and walk in love: Ephesians 5:15 demonstrates that individuals should live as wise people, making the most use of every opportunity that comes their way. This is because we are living in a world that is full of evil and sins.

2.Humanity should respect God and do His will: Humanity should be wise and do the will of God. Morally, each person should examine his ways and make decisions that meet God's will and standards.

3.Humanity should abstain from alcohol: Individuals should abstain from alcoholic beverages or drinks. Alcohol use leads to debauchery (wickedness or sin). Excessive drinking has serious impact on delicate organs in the human body such as the kidney and the liver.

4.Humans should be filled with the spirit of God: We should pray to God to be filled with the Holy Spirit so that we can bear the fruits of the spirit. The fruit of the spirit are love, brotherly kindness, patience, faithfulness and honesty. With these virtues, society will be peaceful and suitable for human habitation.

5.Humans must sing songs to God: Humanity owes God songs of praise and adoration. Therefore, humanity should sing songs and make music in their heart to God. Whenever one is sad, depressed or angry, he should sing songs to the Lord. Refer to Ephesians 5:19.

6.Humanity should be grateful to God: We should be grateful to God for His divine providence and guidance. We should thank Him for all the great things He has done for us.

Islamic Moral Teachings

The Holy Qur'an

The Holy Qur'an has many moral teachings for faithful and humanity in general.

Some of the key moral teachings are as follows:

1.Humanity should be patient: According to Sura 2: 46, Muslims are to be patient even when they are provoked by others. Being patient leads to peace, unity, understanding, freedom, and sound mind to worship and serve Allah.

2.Humanity should be courageous: Humans should be courageous to defend their faith and protect their property from thieves and misfits in society. They -should also stand firm against social ills such as poverty, diseases, hunger and unemployment. Refer to Sura 2:178.

3.One should maintain purity and cleanliness: Muslims also believe that cleanliness is next to Godliness. Humankind should appear decent and clean. The physical body as well as the heart and soul should be clean from sinful acts and deeds. Refer to Sura 5:7.

4.Humanity should be steadfast: Steadfastness means holding fast to the faith and defending it at all times. Humankind shouid be steadfast in their school, work, and domestic chores, social and national duties. Refer to Sura 41 :31.

5.One should be humble: Individuals should be humble to reflect this great virtue exhibited by the Prophet Muhammad and the Caliphs. Refer to Surah 31 :19 to 21.

6.Society should eschew evil acts and deeds: Faithful are exhorted to avoid bad deeds such as drinking alcoholic beverages, abusing illegal substances, prostitution, greediness and criminal acts. Sura 3:11.

African Traditional Religious Wise Sayings

African Traditional Religion has many wise sayings or proverbs that teach humanity useful lessons. Below are some "wise sayings" and their meanings

1.A word to a wise is enough:

Meaning: This means that a child or individual who listens to good advice or counsel will receive blessings and success in life. It is not about telling a lengthy story to a person that may change him or her. Little pieces of advice should be taken in good faith.

2.Patience moves mountains: Meaning: When one restrains himself over issues and wait patiently, one will achieve greater results.

3.Tasty soup (meal) draws seats (people) to itself Meaning: Good behaviour does not have to be advertised, because it is good for its own sake. OR Good behaviour is never denied a due social recognition and so it pays to be good.

4.One finger cannot pick a stone Meaning: lt is easier for people to work together

5.Train the child the way he should go and when he grows he would not depart from it Meaning: Inculcate discipline in the child so that when he grows he will live by it

6.Whatever a man sows is what he reaps Meaning: If you do good, you do it for yourself. If you do bad, you do it for yourself .

7.A crab cannot give birth to a bird Meaning: Birds produce their kind and not crabs so your behaviour reflects your personality

8.The child breaks the shell of a snail and not that of the tortoise Meaning: One should avoid laziness

9.If you do good you do it for yourself Meaning: All good deeds are rewarded

10.You should turn over a new leaf Meaning: You should have a complete change of life from evil to good

11.All work and no play makes Jack a dull boy Meaning: One must have leisure hours

12.If you want to talk to God, you must talk to the wind Meaning: God is everywhere

13.The child needs no one to show him God Meaning: God is with the child

14.There is dignity in labour Meaning: We need to be proud of our work

15.Time is money Meaning: Time is precious

16.A mighty tree has been uprooted or a mighty tree has fallen Meaning: A king has passed away or a great person has passed away

17.A rolling stone gathers no moss: Meaning: The moral lesson is that a busy for nothing person cannot achieve success, prosperity or better life.

18.A lazy man's farm is a breeding ground for snakes: Meaning: One can gain nothing by being lazy. ln other words, it does not pay to be lazy.

19.A gossip betrays a confidence: Meaning: The lesson is that a person who gossips cannot keep a secret

20.No one test the depth of a river with both feet. Meaning: Take time to do your "homework" when considering a new proposition. Do not jump into it blindly without due diligence.

21.Nothing ventured nothing gained: Meaning: One can only succeed by engaging in activities that are productive.

22.When you see clouds gathering, prepare to catch or harvest rainwater. Meaning: Be prepared to look for opportunities to "catch" and turn them into something useful when you see problems surfacing.

23.He who does not cultivate his field will die of hunger. Meaning: Ideas are your seeds, but you need to "plant" those seeds in "fertile soil" in order for them to grow and produce results. lf you do not nurture yourself and your ideas, how can you prosper?

24.A chattering bird builds no nest. Meaning: Stop talking about what you want to do in life... you need to begin doing it! If you do not begin, you can never have what you want.

Moral Teachings in the Wise Sayings from the African Traditional Religion

1.Commitment to God: God is the source of power, wealth, success and providence. As a result humanity must show respect, be committed, and wait patiently on the Lord.

2.Honesty, sincerity and truthfulness: Humanity should cultivate 'these three virtues in their engagements with others in society. Honesty is the best policy in life expected from individuals.

3.Care for life: An individual should take care of himself by living a life that is commendable, respectful, and lawful. His character should be appreciated by society.

4.Love for neighbours: We should demonstrate love for each other by responding to the needs of others. This can be done by assisting those in needs, distressed, sad, and under pressure due to poverty or ill-health. Society must be each other's keeper.

5.Respect for the elderly: As law abiding people in society, we should respect those in authority (teachers), the elderly, our parents, traditional rulers etc.

6.One should be fair to all: Fairness requires that we treat people we associate with as equals. We should not discriminate against another person by virtue of his religion, ethnic group or colour. Humans are created in the image of God.

7.People should be steadfast: One should hold fast to his faith, belief and principles in life. We should not compromise on things that are good, just and worthy of commendation. God blesses those who are steadfast and dedicated to his instructions.

8.Patience, humility,-and obedience: These three virtues are key elements in the moral lessons from the African Traditional Religious teachings. Humankind should cultivate them so as to enhance peace, security, harmony and national unity. Indeed, patience moves mountains.

9.Courage: Individuals should muster courage to persevere in their chosen career. With courage and perseverance, one can overcome obstacles in his life.

Application of Moral Lessons in Our Daily Lives

1.Truthfulness: Society should learn to tell the truth no matter the consequences. God rewards those who speak the truth at all times.

2.Respect for those in authority: One should be prepared to carry out his responsibilities assigned to him by those in authority such as their prefects, teachers, parents, employers and the state.

3.Commitment to God and humanity: Society-should endeavour to show commitment to serve God and their fellow humankind. We should -be each other's keeper and help those in need with humility. One should be humble in everything he does.

4.Care for life: One should care about his physical and spiritual wellbeing. We should live a righteous life and not involve ourselves in sexual immorality, criminal activities and insulting behaviours.

5.Sincerity and trustworthy: These virtues are essential for the survival of humankind. Without trust and sincerity, individuals cannot achieve success in life.

6.Avoid greed and Selfishness: Selfishness, greed, and self-centredness should be avoided by individuals in society. They undermine the growth and development of any society or nation.
2802.name: MORAL TEACHINGS AND COMMITMENT

2803.author: content@ecoachsolutions.com
2803.notes:
REWARD AND PUNISHMENT

GOOD DEEDS AND REWARDS

The objective of this chapter is to:

1.Be aware that good deeds go with rewards and bad deeds go with punishment.

2.Appreciate the consequences of bad deeds and the need for repentance.

Good Deeds

Good deeds are acts, which are correct an are acceptable in the society. Good deeds are actions that are commendable and acceptable by society.

Actions that show good deeds include being respectful, showing concern or love for others, helping others and being patriotic.

Acts of Good Deeds

Below are examples of actions considered as good deeds by society:

1.Helping elderly persons or physically challenged persons by carrying their luggage or load for them.

2.Helping the aged, blind or children to cross a busy road, bridge or drain.

3.Giving up your seat on a bus or at a function to an elderly person, a pregnant woman or sick person.

4.Participating in general cleaning, tree planting exercise and communal labour.

5.Running errands free of charge on behalf of your teacher, parents, friends, classmates and the elderly in society.

6.Helping to carry accident victims, the sick and persons rescued from disasters to the nearest hospital or health facility for medical attention.

7.Reporting known criminals in society to the lawful agencies of state to help them effect arrest and prosecution.

8.Donating in cash and kind such as food, medicines, used clothing, treated nets and water to victims of disaster and the poor in society. God is very grateful when we perform humanitarian services to those in need. Refer to Matthew 25:34 to 36; Luke 17:11 to 16; Sura 9:105; 69:19 to 24.

9.Helping a lost child locate his parents.

10.Providing food for kids whose parents are not at home.

11.Assisting and entertaining the elderly who has been ieft alone at home.

12.Helping to teach someone something he does not understand

13.Picking up litter when someone else drops it and disposing of it safely.

14.Making sure that younger children return home safely from school.

Reward

Good deeds come with rewards or benefits.

A reward is an award or kind gesture that goes to an individual or group in recognition of their good deeds. In short, rewards are the benefits that go with hard work or success.

Rewards are usually given in the hope that the good deeds or behaviour that enabled one to merit them would be repeated.

An individual can be rewarded by the family, school, society, church, and country or world for hard work or good deeds.

Types of Rewards

There are different types of rewards in society. These are as follows:

1.Praises: Praises are words which show approval of something. A school community, family, religious group or country may shower praises on a member for exhibiting hard work or success. For example, Prof. Barima Azumah Nelson, ike Quartey, Alfred Agbeko, and Braimah Kamoko (Bukom Banku) have received showers of praises from Ghanaians for winning world boxing titles for the country.

2.Handshake: In some instances a mere handshake by a prominent member of society is an indication of appreciation of one's hard work. For example, a hand shake by the President of Ghana, a Pastor, an Imam, or Member of Parliament, shows appreciation of one's achievements.

3.Recommendation: A verbal or written notice recommending an individual for what he has done is a form of reward. An individual can be highly recommended by his teacher, lecturer, country or institution of higher leaming to secure a well paid job or an international appointment. Recommendations point out the exemplary qualities such as dedication to duty, hard work, punctuality, selflessness and dependability of the individual concerned. it gives one advantage over those who lack such qualities.

4.Good Testimonial: A testimonial gives a detailed account of an individual's character, academic performance, conduct and behaviour. lt may be used in addition to certificate and curriculum vitae (CV) to seek for employment or pursue higher education.

5.Certificate: An official document which gives credence to certain facts about a person. It qualifies a person as being capable of achieving something.

6.Awards: Society has different forms of- awards to deserving members. Examples are cash prices, books, scholarships, citations, badges and personal computers. This may be given to an individual as a sign of appreciation of hard work. For example, the nation confers various awards on deserving nationals during Independence and Republic Day celebrations. The names of national awards include the Order of the Star of Ghana, the Order of the Star of Volta for both civil and military divisions.

7.Trophies and medals: In sports and other competitions, successful contestants are rewarded with trophies or medals. The trophies and medals range from gold, silver to bronze. The winning team may receive a gold trophy and medals for each participating member to crown their victory or success.

8.Naming monuments after individuals as rewards: Society can reward members who have excelled in different fields like sports, academia, public service etc. by naming important national monuments like roads, stadia, ships, parks, institutions etc. after them. For example, the Prof. Evans Atta Mills High Street was named after H.E Prof. Evans Atta Mills , upon his death as the President of the Republic of Ghana and for his tremendous contribution to the country.

9.Sending a message, cards, telephone calls or just by smiling: You can reward an individual through a smile or by saying "Thank you, God bless you", sending a card to appreciate what he or she did, or by making a telephone call to appreciate a kind gesture.

10.Promotion: A move to a more important job or rank or a move to the next class, etc.

11.Citation: An official statement about something special that somebody has done, etc.

Effects of Rewards

1.It encourages others to work harder or behave properly.

2.It makes people feel elated and recognized.

3.It encourages people especially the youth to be morally upright.

4.It spurs weaker people to buck up in order to have better results.

5.It shows one's gratitude or appreciation for good performance.

6.It can cause one to be swollen headed and become complacent.

7.It can cause a person to resort to wrong means such as cheating in order to do better and be rewarded.

8.It can promote bribery and corruption.

9.It can bring hatred on a person who is always rewarded.

10.It attracts God's blessings.

Reasons for Giving Rewards

1.It serves as motivation to others: When individuals show appreciation to others, it motivates them. Appreciation gingers the individual to continue with the hard work or good deeds. For example, a pupil who receives a price as the best student in class is motivated to study hard to chalk more successes.

2.It serves as encouragement: When you show appreciation to another person for a good deed, it encourages him to give off his best. it helps him to be more focused.

3.It is a requirement from God: God requires that humankind should show appreciation to other humankind. Love your neighbour as your self is a moral lesson for one to show love to others when they do a good job. Refer to Luke 17:11 to 16 about the story of the ten lepers who were cured by Jesus Christ. Only one of them came back to show appreciation and Jesus commended him greatly.

4.Appreciation is a good moral value: Being thankful to God and humanity as a sign of appreciation is a good virtue one must cultivate. Individuals should be grateful to others when they help them out of a situation. Refer to Galatians 5: 13 to 14.

5.It promotes love and good neighbourliness: Learning to show appreciation fosters friendship, love, harmony and good neighbourliness.

6.It enhances peace and harmony: In a multi-ethnic society like Ghana, being grateful and showing appreciation breeds national unity, stability, harmony and peaceful co-existence.

The Moral Significance for Performing Good Deeds

1.It is a commandment from God: Performing good deed is a commandment from God and all religious persons are expected to comply with it. Romans 2:6 and 3:5; 2 Thessalonians 1 :7 to 9.

2.Society expects members to show appreciation: in every society showing appreciation is one of the principles that are inculcated in the upbringing of an individual. As one grows up, he/she is taught to show appreciation for good things done to him by others. Anybody who fails to show appreciation is considered ungrateful.

3.It is a moral responsibility: It is morally acceptable for individuals to show gratitude or appreciation to others when they perform good deeds. All the three main religions in Ghana admonish their members to show appreciation to those who relate very well with them. For example, in Christianity, faithful are expected to do unto others what they want others to do unto them. Therefore, if you expect others to appreciate you, then you should also show appreciation to others.

4.It is a sign of maturity: Matured individuals show appreciation to others for their kind gestures. Anybody who shows appreciation is considered matured.

5.It is a demand by the Holy Books: The Holy Bible, Qur'an and the "Wise Sayings" of the Traditionalist teach members to exhibit a high sense of responsibility and appreciate God and humankind for their support and providence. It is morally right to show appreciation to God and then humans. Refer to Galatians 6:9 to 10.

Bad Deeds and Punishment

Bad Deeds

Bad deeds are acts considered wrong, sinful, unacceptable and criminal or illegal by society. Bad deeds are considered as the works of the flesh by the Bible. Refer to Galatians 5:19 to 20 which states that "The acts of the flesh are obvious: sexual immorality, impurity and debauchery (wickedness); idolatry and witchcraft; hatred, discord, jealousy, fits of rage, selfish ambition, dissensions, factions and envy; drunkenness, orgies, and the like.

Acts considered as bad deeds

1.Telling lies

2.Stealing

3.Cheating or dishonesty

4.Armed robbery

5.Being lawless

6.Jealousy

7.Envy

8.Drunkenness/alcoholism

9.Disobedience to teachers, parents and the elderly in society.

10.Being aggressive towards others

11.Fighting

12.Bullying

13.Substance abuse

14.Murder

15.Rape and defilement

16.Idolatry

17.Sexual immorality

18.Selfish ambition

19.Wickedness

20.Anger

21.Indecent language

22.Indecent dressing or behaviour

23.Negligence of duty

24.Destruction of public property or family property

25.Teaching your friends bad moral habits

26.Occultism

27.Keeping one's environment dirty

28.Collecting money from people after offering them assistance

29.Failing to assist a friend who is in dire need of food or money

Deeds that constitute examination malpractice

1.Copying someone's work during an examination

2.Allowing someone to copy one's work during an examination

3.Impersonation i.e. somebody writing the examination for another person

4.Seeing the question paper before the examination starts

5.Sending a foreign material into the examination hall

6.Parents or teachers attempting to buy question papers for their wards or students

7.Invigilators or supervisors allowing candidates to discuss the questions when the examination is in progress

8.Invigilators leaving the examination hall intentionally

9.Invigilators giving answers to the candidates in or outside the examination hall

10.Candidates exchanging question papers at the time the examination is going on.

11.Candidates writing when they have not been asked to start work

12.Candidates stiil writing when they have been asked to stop work

13.Candidates making unusual bodily gestures like stretching of the neck in an attempt to copy someone's work

14.Candidates exchanging answer booklets when examination is in progress

Why examination maipractices are not good for society

1.Examination malpractices are against school rules and regulations

2.Examination malpractices involve cheating which is against the laws of God

3.Candidates who cheat during exams do not get the blessing of God

4.Candidates who engage in examination malpractice gain undue advantage over their friends

5.Examination malpractices tarnish the image of a school

6.Candidates caught in such acts are rejected by their friends

7.Examination malpractices can retard the growth and development of the society or school or hard work and performance

8.Examination malpractices can lead to the cancellation or withholding of examination results

9.Certificates issued by the examination bodies e.g. WAEC may not be recognized by employers and institutions of higher learning (Polytechnics and Universities)

10.School authorities, invigilators and students caught engaging in examination malpractices may be punished severely e.g. payment of heavy fines or imprisonment

Causes of Bad Deeds

1.Peer pressure or influence: "Evil communication corrupts good morals." When an individual associates himself with deviants or wayward persons, there is the possibility that he may pick some of their bad behaviour.

2.Broken home: Individuals who live in broken homes or are raised by single parents lack parental control. Such children become deviants in society.

3.Poor parenting skills: Some parents fail to inculcate sound moral principles and virtues in their children. Others hardly monitor or have sufficient time to attend to the needs of their children. They fail to give them physical, emotional and spiritual support. As a result some of them grow to become deviant.

4.Psychiatric disorders: Some individuals have mental challenges that adversely affect their sense of judgment. This causes them to engage in acts that society does not accept

5.Rapid Urbanisation: Life in cities and towns has caused some individuals to forget about their moral upbringing. Many people are engaged in prostitution, substance abuse, drug trafficking and stealing in order to survive the high economic hardship in urban centres.

6.Influence by the mass media: Exposure of minors to pornographic and violent scenes on television, magazines and the internet pose a big challenge to the youth in most urban areas. These nude pictures corrupt the moral fibre of the youth.

Effects of Bad Deeds

Anybody who engages in acts that constitute bad deeds is punished

Types of Punishments for Bad Deeds

1.Reprimanding: This involves directly confronting the individual who has committed an offence or bad deed. Harsh (unfriendly) words, threats, or abusive language may be used against the offender to let him know his offence in order to accept responsibility.

2.Physical punishment (corporal punishment): In our educational institutions, bad deeds attract corporal punishment or canning and internal suspension.

However, the Ghana Education Service has rules on caning at school. Some parents and guardian use the rod or cane on their children when they violate laid down rules.

3.Granting of bad testimonial and recommendation: A bad pupil or student may incur the displeasure of his teachers and headmasters to the extent that he may be given a bad testimonial that will jeopardise his future career.

4.Court fine: The court of the land can fine an individual an amount of money for engaging in a bad deed. A person who destroys another person's property may be asked by the court to pay for the item or in default be sentenced to a prison term,

5.Arrest and imprisonment: An individual who is arrested for committing an offence may be prosecuted by the police for court action. The prison term may depend on the gravity of the offence and the circumstance surrounding the crime. Prisons are-meant to reform the individual.

6.Capital punishment (death penalty): Those who commit serious crimes such as murder or high treason may be condemned to death by a court of competent jurisdiction. The death sentences may take the form of hanging, firing squad, electrocution or lethai injections. Though, there is a global cry for the abolition of the death sentence, some countries still practise it.

7.Borstal Institutes: Juveniles who commit serious offences are taken to a training facility called the Borstal institute. They are kept there with limited freedom; they are trained on a preferred vocation, and are taught how best to integrate into society when they are released. Counseilors, pastors, imams and teachers as well as social workers engage them in counselling and training to prepare them for integration into society.

Reasons for Punishing Bad Deeds

Refer to Romans 13: 47 - 48, Ezekiel 18:21 and Surah 18:88, 2: 61

Ezekiel 18:21 states that "But if a wicked man turns away from ail the sins he has committed and keeps all my decrees and does what is just and right, he will surely live; he will not die. People who engage in bad deeds are punished because of the following reasons:

1.To protect society from criminals: Individuals who are engaged in bad deeds are punished to get rid of criminals from society. Through punishments, imprisonment and banishments, society removes bad members and makes it safe and sound for the law abiding individuals.

2.To deter others from committing offences or bad deeds: Punishments are social check against crime and other unacceptable behaviours. When one is punished for committing an offence, it serves as a deterrent to others.

3.To reform the individual: Punishments are meant to reform the individual. Prisons and borstal institutes are meant to teach convicts useful lessons and how to live a morally upright life in society. Caning and reprimands reform an individual.

4.Retribution: One is punished as a reward for bad deeds. For example, when one steals and is caught, he must take the necessary punishment in good faith.

Reasons why Children are punished in schools

-Stealing

-Cheating

-Being truant

-Being violent

-Breaking school rules and regulations

Reasons why we should Avoid Bad Deeds

1.To avoid the prescribed punishment: When one avoids bad deeds, he is free from being punished.

2.To avoid physical pains: Doing the right thing prevents a person from going through pains associated with punishments. For example, when one is caned for violating school rules, he goes through pains.

3.To avoid emotional pains: In other to avoid the shame, teasing, being isolated by friends and loved ones, one should abstain from crime and immoral acts.

4.To avoid depression: One should be mindful of the psychological effects or mental pain associated with doing bad things. Some of the psychological effects are depression, stress, sadness and mental disorders. Depression may take the following forms: reduced interest in social activities; significant weight loss due to low appetite for food; difficulty in sleeping or insomnia; fatigue or loss of energy; problems with concentration when studying and making critical decisions; recurrent thought of committing suicide or death. One can avoid all these problems by not engaging in bad deeds.

5.To avoid sexually transmitted infections: An individual can avoid contracting sexually transmitted infection when he avoids sexual promiscuity

6.To promote peace, security, and unity: When an individual avoids bad deeds such as stealing, armed robbery, prostitution, and substance abuse, there is peace and unity in the society.

7.To aim at living a morally acceptable life: Avoiding bad deeds is a key moral responsibility of an individual in society. Humanity should be inspired to live by the spirit and bear fruits of the spirit. Refer to Galatians 5:22 to 26.

Ways of Accepting Responsibilities For One's Bad Deeds

1.One should be bold and accept the wrongs committed. One must accept responsibility for stealing, cheating, abusing substances or telling lies.

2.After accepting responsibility, one should go ahead to render the necessary apologies for his action. He must show remorse for the bad deed. Showing remorse means that you have regretted your action. This will reduce the pain or hurt the person affected by your action went through.

3.One should discuss openly his wrong deed to a trusted friend or an adult and seek advice. For example, if you are a drug addict, seek advice from a medical doctor or a health professional.

4.One should accept the appropriate punishment for wrongdoing. This will go a long way to restore the lost, trust and stalled relationship.

5.Finally, one should make restitution by paying for what he took, damaged, or destroyed.
2803.name: REWARD AND PUNISHMENT

2804.author: content@ecoachsolutions.com
2804.notes:
RELIGIOUS YOUTH ORGANISATIONS

The objective of this chapter is to help pupils to appreciate the importance of Religious Youth Organizations.

Religious Youth Organizations

Religious youth organisation is an organisation which attempts to seek and provide the religious needs of its members. It is a group of religious people who come together for a common purpose.

Religious Youth Organizations formed within the three main religions in Ghana. The word "youth" refers to a person between the ages 10 to 25 years. However, membership of the youth in the various religious organizations may exceed 25 years.

Youth Organisation in the Three Main Religions in Ghana

Christian Youth Organisations

The main Christian Youth Organisations are:

1.Boys' and Girls' Brigade.

2.Catholic Youth Organizations (C.Y.O.).

3.Pentecost Youth Movement (P.Y.M.).

4.Young Peoples' Guild (Y.P.G.).

1.Boys' and Girls' Brigade; This was formed on 4 October, 1883 at Free College Mission in Glasgow, Scotland by Sir William Alexander Smith. The Ghanaian branch was formed in 1911 by Rev. H.N. Arman.

2.Catholic Youth Organization (C.Y.O.): This was formed in the Roman Catholic Church. The Ghana branch was formed in 1949 by Bishop Adolf Noser. it's motto is "For God and Country.

3.Pentecost Youth Movement (P.Y.M.): This is a youth movement found in the Pentecost Church of Ghana. It has branches in second and tertiary institutions in the country. The Pentecost Students Association (PENSA) is an affiliate of the parent organisation, P.Y.M. Its motto is "Youth Arise and Shine!"

4.Young Peoples Guild (Y.P.G.): This is a youth movement found in the Presbyterian Church of Ghana. Its motto is "To Know His Will And Do It."

Aims and Objectives of Christian Youth Organisations

1.To bring the youth together and train them to take up the mantle of leadership in the future.

2.To organize the youth and redirect their energies for the service of the church and the entire society.

3.To teach the youth sound Christian principles, morals, ethics and virtues that will help them fit well in society and their future endeavours.

4.To teach the youth the Bible to enable them become effective in the spreading of the Good News to those who are lost in the world.

5.To help them gain firm understanding of the teachings of the church so that they can defend their faith at all times.

6.To encourage the youth to organise their own social programmes and to socialize.Through this they able make new friends.

7.To serve as a forum for discussing the numerous challenges facing the youth today in and outside the church.

Islamic Youth Organisations

These are youth organisations found in the various sects under Islam.

They include the following:

1.Muslim Youth Organisation.

2.Ahmadiyya Muslim Youth Organisation.

3.Khuddamul (Ahmadiyya

Aims and Objectives of Islamic Youth Organisations

1.To instill the Muslim youth the spirit of hard work, dedication and selflessness to humanity.

2.To bring all Muslim youth together and teach them how to channel their energies, resources and skills in a more productive way.

3.To prepare them for leadership roles in the future.

4.To incorporate in the youth the principles, teachings, moral standards, faith and practices of Islam.

5.To serve as a forum for discussing challenges facing the Muslim youth and looking for realistic solutions to them.

6.To teach the youth to appreciate and understand the teachings of Allah and His Holy Prophet Muhammad.

7. To encourage them to participate in all Islamic festivals, activities and programmes within the community, educational institutions and the entire country.

Traditional Religious Youth Organisations

Traditional Youth Organisations in Ghana are formed in communities and societies where African Traditional Religion is practised. They include the following:

1.Asafo Companies.

2.Cultural troupes or groups.

Aims and Objectives of Traditional Youth Organisations

1.To bring the youth together to promote the development of their communities.

2.To protect and defend their locality against attacks and those who engage in illegal activities such as illegal mining, chain saw operation and pollution of water bodies. For example, the Ga Youth monitors and arrest individuals and groups that violates the ban on noise making prior to the "Homowo" celebrations.

3.To organise and protect the culture and traditions of the people.

4.To bring the youth together to promote the development of their communities.

5.To promote and preserve a community's cultural heritage and traditions.

6.To teach members about their culture, moral values, beliefs and practices.

Functions of Religious Youth Organisation

1.It helps to promote the spirit of unity, co~operation, and brotherliness among its members.

2.Its members help to ensure peaceful co-existence among people.

3.It helps to instruct members in the moral teachings in the religion in which it operates.

4.It unearth creative qualities, skills and talents in its members e.g. leadership skills.

5.It assists its members to lead good moral lifestyles.

6.It provides a platform for its members to discuss their faith and well-being.

7.Its members carry out developmental projects.

8.It members help to keep the environment clean by organising clean-up exercise, communal labour etc.

9.Its members assist the poor and the needy with financial and material resources.

Moral Teachings of Youth Organisations

The numerous religious youth organisations have many moral lessons they offer to their members. Some of the moral teachings are as follows:

1.They promote unity and togetherness: Members are informed on the need to live together as one people in harmony with people of other faith.

2.They encourage holiness or chastity: Youth organisations teach their-members to abstain from immoral acts such as pre-marital sex, fornication, adultery, substance abuse, prostitution and alcoholism.

3.They train the youth to be honest and sincere: Youth organisations teach members virtues such as honesty and sincerity. This prepares them to fit into the larger community.

4.They incorporate religious principles in the youth: Members are trained to be courageous and hard working. They are encouraged to apply Biblical or Islamic teachings to their private lives.

5.They teach members to persevere: Members of youth organisations must be focused and dedicated to whatever they find themselves doing. This enables them to rely on God for his divine intervention in their daily activities.

6.They teach members to be patriotic: The aims and objectives of most of these youth associations prepare members to be patriotic. They are trained to die a little for the nation.

7.They teach members to be committed: Youth groups ensure that members are committed to their aims and objectives. This inculcates sound moral values to them.

8.They help individuals to be good stewards: Youth organisations train members to acquire leadership qualities for the future. This prepares them to be good caretakers or stewards of the church or mosque.

The Need to Join Youth Organisations or Functions of Youth Organizations

1.They provide an avenue for the youthful population to socialise in a rightful way. Through games and sports or excursions one can make a lot of good friends.

2.They train their members skills such as snail rearing, basketry, tie and dye, sugar craft and soap making that can be a source of livelihood.

3.Members also benefit from information, counselling, lectures, workshops and preaching that prepare them for the future. For example, a counsellor can help an individual to make sound career choices based on information.

4.The individual benefits from moral teachings and virtues that prepare them for the task ahead in the future. The virtues a member can benefit from are honesty, courage, peaceful co-existence, love, faithfulness, unity, kindness and sincerity.

5.Members are also encouraged to take active part in communal labour and national exercises such as immunisation of children against diseases, tree planting exercises, and desilting of chocked drains. This helps members to be responsible citizens.

6.A member of a Youth Organisation can benefit from leadership training. This prepares the individual for leadership roles in the future. For

example, some of the leaders of the church or mosque today were trained in their youthful days by their leaders.

Problems Religious Youth Organizations Face

1.Lack of funding: Difficulty in getting funding for their activities.

2.Lack of time: Difficulty in getting time for their activities.

3.Lack of apathy: Some of the members are lazy to perform religious duties.

4.Extremists' attack: Some of the members are too much committed to their faith and therefore resort to religious fanaticism. Physical and spiritual attacks from those who do not believe in their faith.

5.Lack of resources: Difficulty in getting specific resource persons to speak to them.

6.Lack of commitment: Some of the members are not committed to their course.

7.Lack of effective communication skills: this has led to most youth not knowing the need or reason to join these religious groups, some do not know why the exist.

8.Lust for the world: love for wordly things have made some youth gone into the world seeking their individual interest rather group interest. Some also tend to enage in social vices.
2804.name: RELIGIOUS YOUTH ORGANIZATIONS
