2805.notes:
DECENCY AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE

At the end of this chapter, students will be able to:

1.Appreciate decent behaviours in society.

2.Recognize the adverse effects of substance abuse.

Decency

Decency is said to be a behavior or a social habit or practice that is socially acceptable and does not cause shame or shock. It entails habits or behaviours that show respect, honesty, proper moral behaviour and positive attitudes towards other people.

A person is said to have behaved decently when he is courteous, respectful and cheerful and react to people in a good manner.

Decent Behaviours in Society

1.Having healthy interaction with members of the opposite sex: Boys and girls should relate well on equal terms. No gender is superior over the other. Both males and females have their strengths and weaknesses. What men can do women can also do. Therefore, there is the need to avoid all forms of stereotyping the roles of men and women..

2.Exercising self control: One should not react angrily or violently when insulted, bullied, harassed or laughed at. It is always advisable not to retaliate when provoked.

3.Learn to comport yourself at all times: We should behave well at school, at home, at any social gathering and within the community. For example, we should not interrupt adults when they are engaged in a conversation. We may only do so when our views or consent are needed.

4.Learn to dress appropriately: How we dress speaks conveys a lot of information about us in society. Avoid wearing provocative dresses. A decently dressed person is considered as a well brought up child.

5.Adopt proper eating habits : We should apply table manners when eating. Adhere by all the eating etiquette. An example is by eating quietly without disturbing others nearby: not to be making loud noises when chewing. One should close his or her mouth when chewing.

6.Showing appreciation: We should learn to say "Thank you," when somebody does something for us. For example when somebody offers you a seat, it is always good to say to say thank you. This is decent language that is a sign of a well behaved person.

7.Effective communication: Talking in a group or delivering a message should be done with respect, tactfulness and with the best approaches. We should not exchange words with others especially the elderly in public. We should not shout but speak undertone. This is to prevent others from hearing what we are discussing. We should try as much as possible to tolerate each others views or opinions.

8.We should be respectful in society: Decent behaviour entails showing respect to your parents, teachers, siblings, classmates and the elderly in society. Being respectful to them will attract their blessing and honour.

9.One should cover his/her mouth with a handkerchief or the hand when he/she coughs, sneezes or yawns.

10.One should not sleep when others are talking to him/her or sit when others are standing.

11.We should not undress in the presence of visitors or strangers or walk half- naked or partially dressed in the house.

12.We should not turn our backs to others when they are talking to us.

13.We should not laugh too loud or too much in public

The Need to Lead a Decent Life

1.It brings respect: It serves as the basis for gaining respect from others. People judge you by your appearance. So, to command the respect of others, you must appear decent to the larger society. Decency makes one gain self respect. To be called a lady or gentleman means that you are decent in all spheres of life - talking, dressing, and eating habits and how you communicate.

2.It brings trust and confidence : You will be comfortable dealing with a well dressed person than a shabbily dressed or unkempt person. People tend to associate and easily trust decent individuals.

3.Decency gets us closer to God: As the saying goes "Cleanliness is next to godliness". Being decent is a religious responsibility expected from humanity. As our body is the temple of God, we must appear neat, well mannered and decent in all our appearances.

4.Shows moral upbringing: Decent living is a demonstration that the individual is well brought up. A well trained lady will not expose the private parts of her body to the public.

5.To meet society's expectations : The larger society expects its members to decent. For example, our traditional rulers appear well dressed before they leave their palaces for any occasion. This requires that members of the community should be careful about the way they carry themselves.

Significance of Decency

1.It shows respect for the person and others.

2.It facilitates peace in society.

3.It helps one to make friends easily.

4.It promotes togetherness.

5.It erodes enmity and grudge.

6.It creates a favourable atmosphere where people can interact.

7.It helps to gain the trust of others when one is in need.

8.It promotes admiration from the people in the society.

9.It paves the way for the individual to be seen as a role model by others in society. For example, Mr. Kofi Annan, the former Secretary-General of the United Nations and Mr. John Agyekum Kuffour, ex President of the republic of Ghana are role models because of his decency.

10.Decency goes with rewards and acknowledgment.

SUBSTANCE ABUSE

What is Substance Abuse?

Substance abuse (or drug abuse) is explained as using drugs without medical advice or using a drug, which has not been prescribed by a medical practitioner (doctor) or a physical.

Substance abuse is the excessive consumption or misuse of a substance for the sake of its "desirable" effects on the mind or body, especially drugs or alcohol.

It also involves the wrongful use of legal drugs without medical prescription or the illegal use of banned substances.

Types of Substance Abuse

1.The abuse of legal drugs

2.The abuse of illegal drugs

1.Abuse of legal drugs: Many people buy legal drugs from chemical and pharmacy shops with or without prescription and abuse them. The legal drugs commonly abused include painkillers like Paracetamol, drugs on flu, antacid (Andrews salt), anti malarial drugs (artesunate-amodiaquine), Vitamins B and C supplements, antibiotics, tobacco, and alcohol. These drugs can be bought over the counter.

2.Abuse of illegal drugs: these are drugs or substances that are banned by law. They include cocaine, heroin, cannabis ("wee" or marijuana), crack (free base cocaine that can be smoked) and "hashish (the sticky resin from cannabis plant). Illegal drugs can be very addictive. This means that a person will want to keep taking the drug. They are also bad for people, damaging their health, causing diseases and even death when taken in overdose. Illegal drugs are processed and used in medicine to treat special conditions but are not meant to be used by the public in its raw state, even in that case excessive use can be dangerous.

Classification Of Substances (Drugs) that are Abused and their Effects

Abused substances or drugs are classified or grouped into three. They are:

1.Hallucinogens.

2.Stimulants.

3.Depressants.

1.Hallucinogens:These are drugs that modify an individual's perception, experiences and his way of thinking. An example is marijuana or wee (Indian hemp). It is abused in the form of the dried leaves and seeds. It can be smoked, eaten, boiled and drunk like a beverage. The active ingredient in marijuana is tetrahydrocannabinol (THC)-. Other hallucinogens include inhalant drugs like glue and thinner which can cause heart attack and possibly death.

Effects of Marijuana

1.Increased heart beat

2.Dry mouth and throat.

3.Increased blood pressure.

4.Impaired immune system that makes the individual prone to infections.

5.Fatigue, making the individual inactive.

6.Inability of the Central Nervous System to function effectively.

7.It alters one's perception about many things in life.

8.High doses can lead to madness or heart attack and sudden death.

2.Stimulants: These are drugs that increase activity in the brain. These drugs can temporarily elevate alertness, mood and awareness. Examples of stimulants are caffeine, nicotine, cocaine, and amphetamines.

Caffine:

Caffeine is found in cocoa, tea, coffee and some prescribed drugs. It has several positive effects such as increasing energy level and mental alertness.

Excessive use of caffeine has the following effects on the individual:

1.It can lead to increased heart beat, heart diseases and attacks.

2.It excites the spinal cord and nerves.

3.Over production of acids in the stomach that can lead to irritation in the stomach.

4.It can damage the central nervous system leading to disruptions in sleep, mood change, anxiety, depression, headaches, vomiting, gastric ulcers, irregular heartbeat and stomach pains.

Nicotine:

This is the active ingredient or chemical found in tobacco or cigarette. Tobacco has over 4,000 chemical compounds. These chemicals are all very harmful to the smoker and those close to him (passive smokers) as he smokes.

Effects of Nicotine on the individual:

1.Nicotine is a highly addictive drug that produces chronic irritation of the respiration system.

2.It alters the mood of the individual by producing pleasurable effects.

3.It stimulates the adrenal glands, the brain and spinal cord.

4.It destroys the sense of taste causin the individual to lose appetite for food.

5.Smoking leads to reduced rate of lung growth and functions.

6.Young people who smoke are less fit for most tasks including studying and engaging in sports.

7.Smoking leads to shortness of breath, coughing and gradual diminishing of health.

8.It contributes to chronic throat infections and bronchitis.

9.Smoking is largely responsible for major cancers of the tongue, lungs, mouth, oesophagus and pancreas.

10.It contributes to stroke and sudden death.

Cocaine:

This is a stimulant that is produced from the coca plant. The drug can be sniffed (inhaled), taken orally, or injected through the veins. It is a hard drug that stimulates the central nervous system and very addictive.

When injected, it reaches the brain quickly and is then distributed to other tissues in the body.

Effects of cocaine on the individual

1.It narrows the blood vessels. This may result in increased heart beat, blood pressure and rapid respiration.

2.It leads to rapid excitement, decreased fatigue or tiredness and increased alertness.

3.It also leads to inactiveness, less interest in work and performing one's responsibilities.

4.Excessive use leads to delusions, hallucination, unrealistic thinking or paranoia.

5.It contributes to the rupturing of blood vessels leading to heart attacks, stroke and epilepsy.

6.It increases aggressiveness, anxiety and sleeplessness or insomnia.

7.It leads to loss of appetite

8.It increases the risk of sexually transmitted diseases especially HlV/AIDS through the sharing of needles.

9.It leads to increased depression, overdependence and chronic fatigue.

10.It increases rate of suicide, heart attacks, mental disorders, and sudden death.

Amphetamines:

These are stimulants that are only prescribed by medical doctors (legal drugs), but are abused.

Some students use it to stimulate the central nervous system in order to keep wake at night to study. Others use it as a drug to control their weight.

Effects of Amphetamines on the individual

1.Regular use may lead to impulse reaction and out of control behaviour such as fighting and aggression.

2.It may lead to convulsion

3.Sleeplessness

4.Malnutrition

5.Mild usage increases alertness, excitement, and decreases in fatigue and weight loss.

6.Hypertension and possibly death.

3.Depressants:

These are drugs that slow down the central nervous -system, bodily functions and behaviour.

Medically, depressants are used to reduce anxiety, induce sleep and help patients to relax.

Depressants can also be addictiveif taken over a period of time.

Examples of depressants are alcohol, barbiturates, tranquilizers and opiates (narcotics). Depressants are generaliy called sedatives by doctors and health professionals.

Alcohol:

This is a legal drug that is mostly abused.When taken; it slows down the activities of the brain. It is found in beer, pito, gin, palm wine, whisky, "akpeteshie", some types of etc.

Raw alcohol is used as a solvent in many industrial activities. It is also used to preserve substances in the laboratory and also to sterilise some instruments.

Despite its wider usage, it has detrimental effects on humans when it is used excessively.

Effects of alcohol on humans:

1.It destroys important tissues and organs in the body such kidney, liver, heart muscles, and pancreas

2.Excessive intake causes diabetes and destruction of tissues and brain cells.

3.Alcohol use is associated with violent behaviour, conflicts, crime, rape, defilement, spousal abuse, child neglect and sexual immorality (adultery).

4.It reduces one's ability to think clearly and reduce resistance and defences. For example, a drunken lady easily gives in to sexual advances from "anybody"or could easily be raped.

5.Excessive intake of alcohol can lead to sudden death of the individual due to heart failure.

6.When pregnant women use alcohol in excess, it leads to Fatal Alcohol Syndrome (FAS). This is characterised by severe birth defects in the child such as mental defects, impaired memory, poor academic performance,'still birth (death of the child in the womb), facial abnormalities and small or over sized head circumference.

7.It inhibits and impairs the individual's sense of judgment. It affects one's vision, perception, judgment and reaction time to situations and the ability to control speed.

8.Alcoholism is largely responsible for many accidental deaths such as drowning, deaths caused by falling from high rise buildings and domestic accidents.

Barbiturates

These are depressants that act on the central nervous system and cause drowsiness. The drugs make people very relaxed, calm, and sleepy. They are sometimes used to help patients relax before surgery. Some may also be used to control seizures (convulsions).

Barbiturates are available only with a physician's prescription and are sold in capsule, tablet, liquid, and injectable forms. Some commonly used barbiturates are Phenobarbital (Barbita) and Secobarbital (Seconal). Barbiturates in recent times have been replaced by other drugs.

Tranquilizers

Tranquilizers are drugs used to treat anxiety or problems with sleep. They have a calming effect by depressing the nervous system in a way similar to alcohol. These drugs are mostly prescribed for patients with psychiatric problems. The drugs are frequently abused because of their ability to reduce anxiety. They are addictive because tolerance develops rapidly, and more and more are needed to be effective. The most commonly known forms of tranquilizers are Xanax, Ativan, Valium, and Librium.

Narcotics:

These are depressant drugs that act on the brain to inhibit the perception of pain. Examples of narcotics are opium, morphine, codeine and heroin.

Opium is naturally derived from the poppy plant. It is either smoked or sniffed in the form of a powder.

Morphine is produced from opium. They are legal drugs prescribed by doctors to patients with severe pain.

Codeine is also a legal narcotic painkiller produced from morphine. They include Paracetamol, Drastin, F-Pack, BX and the others for relieving pain.

Heroin is a white narcotic drug produced from morphine. It is used to slow down body functions such as heart beat, breathing and the production of drowsiness. It is mostly injected through the veins to produce or relief the individual of pain.

Effects of Excessive use of Narcotics

1.They produce euphoric (joyful) feelings, drowsiness, nausea and the relief of extreme pain.

2.They can cause the individual to behave violently.

3.The use of a single needle to administer heroin can lead to the spread of sexually transmitted infections.

4.When used in excess, they cause convulsion, coma and possibly death.

Causes of Substance Abuse

1.Economic hardship and stress: Unemployment, poverty, financial difficulty, and general helplessness put stress on individuals to use depressants like alcohol to induce sleep and to relax. Some people believe that it relieves them off their problems; however alcohol has never proved to be a permanent solution.

2.Self â€“medication: Many people use legal drugs as and when they wish. Some take over dose, use drugs indiscriminately, and others buy from the counter with or without prescription and use them on their own way. All these practices amount to substance abuse.

3.Peer pressure: Many people abuse drugs due to misinformation and pressure from their peers. They smoke, inhale, drink and inject drugs because their peers have told them about the "good feelings" they get from the drugs.

4.Curiosity: Drug use may be as a result of curiosity. People want to have a feel of drugs out of curiosity. By experimenting with drugs, the individual becomes addicted and finds it difï¬cult to quit.

5.Ignorance: Many people abuse drugs especially legal drugs because they do not know the effects on their body. Inadequate information by teachers, pastors, parents, and peer educators on the adverse effects of drug abuse largely contributes to drug abuse.

6.Advertisement by the media: The uncontrolled exposure of the youth to legal drugs like alcohol and cigarettes has contributed to increased substance abuse. Persuasive adverts on television, radio, and the internet about alcoholic beverages by some icons in society makes it appealing to people who easily hook onto it.

7.Ineffective parenting: Broken homes and ineffective parenting contributes to deviant behaviour, which includes substance abuse. Some parents are involved in substance abuse and therefore, not able to discipline or control their children who are also involved.

8.Emotional stress: Sometimes, emotional problem can cause an individual to abuse drugs. Alcohol is mostly used by people to overcome unpalatable situations. Some individuals abuse drugs like alcohol because it reliefs them of boredom, tension, stress and economic difficulty.

9.Lack of self-control or self discipline: Some students abuse drugs simply because they are unable to control themselves. These can be associated with addiction.

10.For high academic achievement: Some students believe that certain drugs can help them stay awake and study late into the night so that they can perform well in exams.

11.Rebellion against authority:Students resort to illegal drugs to enable them become bold and fearless so that they may rebel against authority.

12.Immoral living: substance abuse sometimes make students or people to behave abnormally, through these they engage in social vices without thinking about the implications of it.

Effects of Substance Abuse

1.It damages the brain by causing lapses in memory and exaggerating reactions to events.

2.It cause mood swings.

3.It disrupts regular sleep or wake patterns.

4.It causes madness.

5.It causes hallucinations.

6.It causes anxiety and stimulates the nervous system.

7.It causes physical damage to the body.

8.It causes one to fail to respond to events in the environment,

9.It blocks the ability to make sound judgement.

10.It causes marriages to break down.

11.It causes diseases.

12.It gives 'false' confidence.

13.It puts one on "high", a situation which can lead him to commit murder.

14.It enables people to engage in criminal acts like armed robbery and rape.

15.It stimulates frustration and anger.

How to Prevent or Control Substance Abuse

1.Public education on substance abuse: Early intervention through school-based educational programmes on the harmful effects of substance abuse must be put in place. This should form part of the educational curriculum.

Peer led educational programmes should also be introduced at schools, religious groupings, and within the community to improve on access to information on the harmful effects of substance abuse.

Parents, religious leaders, the media, the police, social welfare, role models, and counsellors should also be brought on board to help inform the youth and adolescents on the dangers associated with abusing drugs.

2.Implementation of government policies on drug peddling and trafficking: The Ghana Police Service and the Narcotic Control Board should team up to deal ruthlessly with known drug barons within the society. The punishment for drug peddling and trafficking should be strictly enforced without any fear or favour. They should be monitored closely and arrested. The Police and the Judiciary must work hand-in-hand to deal with all drug related offences.

The security agencies should organise regular swoops at hide outs of drug dealers, traffickers and users. This will help bring peace in society. Marijuana farms should be identified and destroyed. The offenders must be dealt with by the laws of the state.

3.Laws against self-medication: legal drugs should never be boughjt without a prescription. Pharmacists and licensed chemist should be charged never to sell drugs off the counter without proper prescription; any one who goes contrary to this should be prosecuted.

4.Improvement in mental health facilities: The current state of the mental health facilities in the country should be improved. New facilities should be established in other regions to reduce pressure on the existing ones. Mental Health Professionals should be well trained and motivated in order to perform their duties with diligence.

5.Improved media relation and advertisement: The Food and Drugs Board, the Ghana Standard Board and other relevant state institutions should ensure that advertisement on alcoholic beverages and cigarettes are regulated and controlled. Media advertisement should be strictly scrutinized and highly censored. Any media house that fails to comply with the regulation should be sanctioned. Role models should rather use the medium to advise people to desist from substance abuse.

6.International co-operation on the drug trade: The Government of Ghana and the security agencies should collaborate with international organisations such as lnternational Criminal Police Organization (INTERPOL) to track the movement of hard drugs and banned substances from South America and other destinations into the country.

This will reduce the inflow of drugs into the country. A monitoring scheme must be put in place to trace the movement of drug barons, traffickers, and drug peddlers. Informants should be used to follow the operations of drug dealers.

Reasons why the individual should Avoid Substance Abuse

1.To be able to live a decent and healthy life: We should avoid abusing drugs in order to live a decent and healthy life. This is because drugs are harmful to our body. It destroys the body in several ways, causing heart and kidney diseases.

2.To avoid the health risks associated with drugs: A drug addict exposes his body and other delicate organs to many health risks. Drugs damage organs like the brain, the liver, the kidney, the lungs, the stomach, the pancreas, and the tongue.

3.To ensure progress in life: A person who does not take drugs is able to make sound judgment. He is able to achieve success in whatever field he or she finds his or herself.

4.To maintain peace in the family and society: A drug-free person makes sound decisions and actions that foster peace, harmony, and stability in the family and the larger society. He is able to improve on his self-esteem and avoid relationship that has the potential of undermining the family.

5.To maintain the family's good image/identity: We should avoid engaging in drugs that are capable of destroying our lives and the family's good image. No family is pleased to have a member who is a drug addict or is mentally unstable because of drugs.

6.To protect and maintain the body which is the temple of God: A person who does not engaged in drugs is well kept and decent in whatever he does. He or she tends to live a moral life hence drawing him closer to God.

7.To avoid difficult relationships: One who abstains from drugs is able to engage in a relationship devoid of fighting, abuse, rape, molestations and stress. For example a fiancÃ©e who is a drunkard cannot sustain a peaceful and conflict free relationship. This is because of lack of understanding, suspicion, mistrust, mood changes and confusion on simple issues.

8.To avoid arrest and imprisonment: Using banned substances may cause one to be arrested and prosecuted by the law enforcement agencies. One may spend so many years in jail for abusing drugs and for engaging in crime under the influence drugs.

Defensive Skills That Protect and Defend an Individual against Substance Abuse

The following skills will guide the individual to resist the temptation to abuse drugs:

1.Use assertive behaviour: Look directly into the eyes of the person influencing you to take a drug and say "NO". Be firm, clear and state your reasons for refusing it. Repeat the statement or reason if he insists and do not change your position. Let your "No" be "No". Never thank a person who is forcing you to take a drug. Just insist on your "NO".

2.Use non-verbal behaviour that matches your stand or position on drugs: Actions, they say speak louder than words. Therefore, do not pretend to smoke or sip an alcoholic beverage. This will send wrong signals to those who are abusing it. Let your facial expression and body language tell them that you are not interested in their bad acts.

3.Avoid situations that drugs may be abused: Never remain at a place when it is clear that alcohol, cigarette, and other drugs are going to be used or abused. For example, do not attend a friend's party if you are aware that they are going to serve alcoholic beverages. The wise thing to do is to excuse yourself.

4.Avoid bad friends and company: Do not engage with colleagues and individuals who do not show decent behaviour or have suspicious character. Some of them may be drug users and therefore, can easily force you into drug use. Remember that evil communication corrupt good morals and the mind. Do not associate with peers and friends who abuse drugs. They will convince you to join their evil and harmful acts.

5.Avoid eating food or drinks offered by people you do not trust: Do not eat any food or drink when you suspect that the person giving it to you is interested in you. There could be a drug in the food. Do not leave your food or drink with people at a party when you have doubt about their credibility and honesty. Take your drink before going to dance or visit the lavatory. Someone can put a drug in your food or drink in order to take advantage of you.

6.Keep to your religious teachings on drugs: Drugs are harmful and dangerous to the temple of God, which is your body. As children of the Most High God, keep away from drugs that can harm your body.

7.Discuss your problems and curiosity on drugs: Openly discuss your personal problems with your teachers, parents, religious leaders and peer educators so that they can give you the right answers, solutions and advice. They will inform you on the dangers of abusing drugs.

Remember that a "Well informed person has the greatest asset against drugs and related issues." This will make you assertive and live a drug-free life.

8.Putting into practice the moral teachings of one's religious faith

9.Following instructions on how certain drugs should be used.

10.Avoiding self-medication and buying drugs off the counter.
